This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS
GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MERSINE, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon.Every monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.p: A Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:

A Restaurant car is attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo to Luxor and vice versa three times a week, from Cairo on Mondays, Wednesday, and Saturdays and from Luxor on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Sundays.

div.head: TURKISH SUCCESSION.
div.p: M. de Lanessan, the eminent director of the "Siècle," has written a remarkable article on the Turkish succession. After referring to the intrigues for altering the legitimate order of succession, and of placing Burhaneddin Effendi, the 22 years old son of Abdul Hamid, on the throne after his father's death, the ex-Minister of the Marine shows that the strong liberal movement in the Ottoman Empire makes the success of such an enterprise more than problematical. M. de Lanessan adds: "So long as Abdul Hamid preserved intact all his physical and mental faculties, his subjects who are yearning for liberty were reduced to silence. To-day they already breathe more freely. After the Sultan's death they will be strong enough, and their number will have increased sufficiently to make it impossible for a palace revolution to prevent the advent to the throne of Reshad Effendi, or to hinder public opinion from pronouncing in favour of the establishment of a constitutional régime. The formula adopted by all the liberal elements of Turkey may be summed up as follows : The establishment of a Liberal Constitution and the protection of the Empire against all the causes of dislocation or destruction with which it may be threatened.

"Germany having shown herself to be the auxiliary of Abdul Hamid's abhorred despotism, and not having shown how to restrain her ambitions or cupidity, it is quite natural that the populations of Turkey should distrust her. On the other hand, the sympathies of the Liberals are with France and England, who have constantly shown themselves favourable to the institution of the Liberal régime, and who respect the integrity of the Ottoman Empire. The moment has come for these two Powers to prove their fidelity to the policy which they have always proclaimed. Certainly they would outstep their role by intervening in the internal events which may occur at the moment of Abdul Hamid's death. It belongs to the Liberal Party of the Ottoman Empire to take care that the rights of Reshad Effendi are respected. But the Liberals must know that France and England follow their efforts with lively sympathy and desire their advent to power."

Recently a good deal of conflicting information has been published concerning Reshad Effendi, the presumptive heir to the Turkish throne. He has been described by some people so ill with diabetes that he is not likely to survive Abdul Hamid, and by others as being a complete nullity from an intellectual point of view. Reliable information about Reshad Effendi, is supplied by Prince Sebaheddine, whose mother is the sister of both Abdul Hamid and Reshad Effendi, Of all the Turkish refugees in Western Europe he is probably the best qualified man to speak of the presumptive heir to the Ottoman throne, because, with his father, Mahmoud Pasha, he was before his flight to France subjected to much the same sequestration as his uncle.

"Reshad Effendi, far from being decrepit, is, said Prince Sebaheddine, both mentally and physically alert. He has, it is true, suffered from diabetes, but the remedies and the precautions he has taken have had the desired effect, so that it is probable it will not be of that malady he will die. Nor is he ignorant of what has taken place during the last thirty years. On the contrary, he has been kept acquainted with everything, and has occupied his mind with study. His moral character is the opposite of that of Abdul Hamid. All the privations inflicted on him during his long years of imprisonment in his palace have not soured his temper or inspired in him a thirst for revenge. On the contrary, Prince Sebaheddine assured me that he would be merciful even to his bitterest enemies, and that his one desire is to give all the races of which, the Ottoman Empire is composed a régime of justice and constitutional liberty insuring their material and moral well-being."

He also declared that he did not believe any attempt to place another member of the Imperial family on the throne after the death of Abdul Hamid could be successful. If, for instance, one of the sons of Abdul Hamid were by a palace intrigue proclaimed Sultan, the popular movement against such a usurpation would be so strong as to sweep the illegitimate Sultan away. Fear has been expressed that the Imperial Guard constituted by Abdul Hamid might impose on the Empire the man of their choice as his successor. Prince Sebaheddine does not share that apprehension, because the Imperial Guard is composed chiefly of three conflicting elements: Albanians, Kurds, and Turks. Moreover, it numbers no more than about 12,000 men, and Constantinople is garrisoned by 40,000 regular troops opposed to any sort of modification in the traditional order of succession.

div.head: Legislative Council.
div.p: The meeting of the Legislative Council which was to have been held yesterday was postponed on account of there not being a quorum.

div.head: Homeward Bound
div.p: The transport Dongola arrived at Port Said yesterday morning from Bombay with 1,733 troops from India, and left for Southampton at 5 p.m.

div.head: Cattle Markets.
div.p: An order of the Ministry of the Interior authorises the reopening of the cattle markets in the Bebera and Sharkieh provinces for all kinds of animals.

div.head: Six Months for a Buffalo.
div.p: The Damanbour Parquet yesterday sentenced a boy of 14 to six months imprisonment for shooting a boffalo belonging to a person against whom he had a grudge.

div.head: Al Azhar.
div.p: We hear that Sheikh Mohamed Shakir will probably be named sab-warden of Al Azhar, and will be replaced at Alexandria by Sheikh Mohamed Hassanein El Adawi.

div.head: Helouan.
div.p: We understand that there is no truth in the report that diphtheria has broken out at Helouan, and that the health of that popular winter resort is in every way highly satisfactory.

div.head: Troops for the Yemen.
div.p: The Turkish transport Babr Djedid arrived at Port Said yesterday morning from Turkey and Syria, having on board 600 troops who'd are on their way to join General Faizi Pasha's army. The Bahr Djedid entered the Canal at midday.

div.head: Alexandria Horticultural Society.
div.p: The Chrysanthemum Show which will be opened at San Stefano on Saturday next will remain open on Sunday also. The Show promises to be very successful. We understand that the applications for space are larger than they have ever been before.

div.head: A Government Club,
div.p: Mr. Mitchell Innes, Under Secretary of State for Finance, is about to found a club for Government employés. It is said that the Government will make a free grant for thirty years of a plot of land at Ghézireh facing the Kasr-el-Nil terrace for the club building.

div.head: Band Performance.
div.p: By kind permission of Lieut. Colonel E. A. Herbert, M.V.O., and officers, the string band of the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons will play at the Continental Hotel, Cairo, tomorrow (Wednesday) during and after dinner. Dinners are now served in the big dining hall of the hotel.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Last week, 8 cases of plague were recorded, 4 at Alexandria, 2 at Baez, one at Port Said, and one near Tantsh, bringing the total for the year up to 508, against 818 and 264 in the corresponding period of the years 1904 and 1905 respectively. To-day's bulletin records five cases in the Samalout district. These cases were discovered in the village of Bakarlank on the 26th, 27th, and 28th inst.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: On the 27th and 28th October, 14 vessels, of which 2 were northward and 12 southward bound, transited the canal, and paid for transit and passenger toll Fr. 364,471.14. Of these, 9 were British, 2 German, 1 American, 1 Italian, and 1 Dutch. The total receipts since October 1 are Fr. 7,399,464.41, and during that time 283 vessels transited the Canal, 128 being northward and 155 southward bound.

div.head: Are Idols Made In Birmingham?
div.p: A speaker at a Blackburn meeting said that idols were made in Birmingham. Bishop Thornton strongly dissented. As an old Birmingham man he felt indignant at the charge, and said, if true, it was in the highest degree disgraceful. The speaker having given the name of his informant, the Bishop exclaimed, "I will go to Birmingham and thresh this thing out. If there is a firm in the city manufacturing idols for Paganism, I shall expose them to the whole 1 country.”

div.head: Faction Fight in Cairo.
div.p: Forty-six arrests have been made in connection with an affray between Saidis and Cairenes in the Sharia Masrouf, Cairo. Twenty persons were injured. The proprietor of a café next door to the one where the riot took place was badly knocked about, his skull being slightly fractured. A waiter in the same café had his right arm broken. The affair seems to have been simply a faction fight, in which nabouts were used with a great disregard of consequences

div.head: Future of Malta.
div.p: Does the Island of Malta tilt periodically or slowly sway like some gigantic rocking-stone upon some gigantic pivot? For a long time certain phenomena of the tideless sea rising and falling in the harbours and other indications have given rise to the tilt theory. The seismograph ingeniously set up in the past at the dockyard, and recently the beautiful new Milne seismograph, established on the foundation-rock of the University, confirm the preside. The island may therefore yet became of interest to scientific men.

div.head:
THE NOUVEAUTES INCIDENT.
YESTERDAY'S EVIDENCE.
div.p: The hearing of the action brought against M988rs. L. — and G. — by M. Lauri for disorderly conduct and assault on the 21st inst. was concluded yesterday.

Further evidence was called by the prosecution and M. Salman was cross-examined by Mr. Le Breton, representing Mr. L.— He stated that he did not himself see defendants throwing chairs, nor was be a witness of the actual assault on the writer.

The police witnesses were then called. Constable Antonio Gellal, sworn, gave evidence in Maltese, stating that he was on the box of the carriage which drove away first towards Shepheard's, then to the caracol. He was seized by the tunic by both defendants when they arrived. After this he was struck by & whip. The defendant G.-— hit him and the horses with the whip — some twenty times.

Then came the mamour el kism. He said that he was in bed on the night of the affair and was roused by a noise. A policeman made a communication to him. He looked out of the window and saw a scuffle between the police and two Englishmen who were in a cab. He went down and took their names, etc., for the procés verbal. He then went with defendants towards Shepheard's, but as defendants had no money they stopped and went to the St. James's Bar. Their appearance excited remark there. Of the defendants, Mr. L.— was "sakran' awi," the other was more in possession of his faculties. Next day one of the defendants called on him and asked him to give absolutely fair evidence, stating that he did not know what had happened. On Sunday both saw him.
After some further evidence the Court asked witness if he had been offered anything by defendants. Witness replied in the negative.

Defendants were then sworn, and gave evidence. Mr. G., after giving an inventory of the drinks consumed on the fatal night, and stating that he had a strong head, said that the party did not try to get into the stage entrance bat merely went to find the lavatory. They did not know the arrangements of the theatre. They were not interrupting the performers, merely singing the chorus of "The Old Ball and Bush," a song resembling which was being given.

He admitted pushing the waiter out because the waiter breathed on him and put his hands, which were dirty, on his clothes. Mr. L. was sitting with his legs over the box because he had no room in the box. Neither was drunk. He admitted thrusting the proprietor out. As for the scuffle, the crowd hustled and attacked them. At the caracol there was an excited crowd, and as he had been knocked about, and did not want to leave the carriage because of their demeanor, he took the reins and hit the horses with his whip to get the carriage away. Some of his blows may have struck a policeman, but he did not mean to hit any person. Witness said he spoke no Arabic or French. Mr.L—, on being sworn gave a similar account. He said that he remembered very little, having been hit on the head in the scuffle. After the waiter was put out of the box the party left, but then someone said "it's all right now" and they went back. He did not know what had happened, nor why they left the box.

Evidence for the defence emphasised the gesticulations of the waiter and the excitement of the crowd. Mr. Le Breton, on behalf of Mr. L— pleaded that his client had not been proved guilty of any assault.

Mr. Alban stated that the defendants had been guilty of disgraceful conduct and that he considered that the case against them had been fully made out. He would sentence them to 14 days' imprisonment each without the option of a fine.
Proceedings closed at 1.20 p.m.

div.head: AL AZHAR UNIVERSITY.
div.p: The chancellor of Al Azhar University has intimated to the Khedive his desire to resign, but his Highness has asked him to reconsider his decision, and put the matter before him again after a month's deliberation. During Ramadan Sheikh Abdon el Fadl is acting as chancellor.

Sheikh Mohamed Shakir, president of the Alexandria board of the ulema, will probably be appointed sub chancellor of the University in the near future, and in such a case he will be succeeded on the board of ulema, by Sheikh Mohamed Hassanein el Adawi.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive came to Ras-el Tin from Montazah this morning. Hossein Pasha Moharrem, A.D.C. to His Highness, returned to Alexandria from Cairo yesterday afternoon.

div.head: THE NEW MINISTER.
NATIVE PRESS COMMENTS.
div.p: On Sunday Saad Bey Zagleul, the new Minister of Education, had a private audience with the Khedive, and, returning to Cairo the same evening, paid visits to the Ministers and Advisers, from all of whom he received hearty congratulations on his new appointment.
It is confidently expected that the Khedive will shortly con for the rank of Mirmiran upon the new Minister, who will then hold the same grade as his fellow ministers.
It is also rumoured that Yacoub Pasba Artin, Under-Secretary of State of Education, will resign shortly.
The following are translations of the comments of the native Press on the new appointment.
Most important Ministry.

From "Al Mokattam":—The Ministry of Public Instruction is perhaps the most important of all the ministries, and there is ample room for reform. It cannot be doubted that this ministry has in the past done everything possible for the advancement of education in this country, and Saad Bey Zagloul himself acknowledged this when the circular of the provisional committee for the establishment of a national university was issued...... The people of the country will now look to Saad Bey Zaglool to devote his talent and his energy to the progression of public education in such a way as to gain the satisfaction of the nation.
A Welcome Augury.

"Al Moayad":—Diring the past eleven years our Ministry has remained the same, impassable on account of its inaction, always tranquil, and always identical; up to the present all power has fallen upon the English Advisers. Bat now we have been wakened with a start. A loud bang has roused us from our torpor; it concerns a new "combination" in our ministry. This combination instills in us new hope, for we can only attribute it to the desire of the Sovereign and his Advisers to render to the Ministers a certain measure of their old powers. After what has happened among us to make the Egyptians discontented, we would hope that instructions to that effect have been given by the English Minister for Foreign Affairs… It is to his eminent virtues, the independence of his character, and his personal dignity that Saad Bey Zagloul owes his promotiou to this high post.
Suggested by Prime Minister.

"Al Minbar":—Some people may consider that the new Minister cannot fail to follow in the footsteps of his colleagues in his relations with the Adviser, bat we are of the opinion that Mr. Danlop cannot but co-operate with such a Minister as Saad Bey Zagloul for the advancement of the nation by ever raising the standard of education. Some persons are of the opinion that the appointment of Saad Bey Zagloul was suggested by Mustapha Pasha Febmy, whose chief aim has always been to avoid any strained relations between the English and Egyptians, and it is also rumoured that the Prime Minister will shortly resign with the object of facilitating the accession of Saad Bey Zagloul to the presidency of the Council of Ministers.
Extent of Power.

"Al Ahram":—In some quarters it is thought that Saad Bey Zagloul's appointment is a forerunner of the resignation of Mustapha Pasha Febmy, while others say that Lord Cromer, having taken to heart the criticisms passed upon the policy of education in Egypt, has appointed Saad Bey Zagloul to satisfy the public. We are of the opinion that if the government, who has overlooked Ibrahim Pasha Naguib, Ismail Pasha Sabri, Artin Pasha, and Saleh Pasha Sabet, means to give Saad Bey Zagloul, whose talent makes him deserve the post, freedom in the education and the organisation of the Ministry, the appointment will prove an excellent one, but, otherwise, a new Minister, who is allowed to do nothing, would give satisfaction to nobody.
An Effect of Denishwai.

"Al Lewe":—The appointment of Saad Bey Zaglool is an after-effect of the Denishwai incident, which caused the Egyptians to show how they shrink from the British Occupation, which robs them of their independence and influence. But the new departure will please none of us unless Saad Bey Zagloul is allowed freedom of action in his new post. The new Minister should at once seize the opportunity to prove his er energy and talent.

div.head: "SERGEANT BRUE.”
div.p: "Sergeant Brue" proved to be less uninteresting than its two predecessors; but again we have to complain that it is but a one-man piece, and is as full as any of its kind of songs which have no sort of reference to the action. These we can sometimes pardon "While you wait" and "Ha, ha, ha, he, he, he" both gave Mr. Cole a good ILLEGIBLE, and he used it to effect. Mr. Cole, indeed, did his best all through, and accentuated such points as his part contained to the utmost, Miss Corlass hardly had a fair chance but she, too, made much of a most colourless part. Mr. Will Smith was good as the low-down "man of all work." The best song from a vocal and musical point of view was Mr. Attwell's "Eyes of Blue," through the "Congo," by Miss Morra, and the "Isle of Erin," by Miss Leslie, were both very fairly given.

The orchestra was rather weird at times, but possibly that may have been intended by the composer. It is rather a hopeless case for English musical comedy of to-day, if "Sergeant Broe" and "The Catch of the Season" are to be taken as representative; and the company have a hard task before them if "The Little Michus" and the other more modern pieces are no better. They have shown in "The Runaway Girl" what they can do, and it is unfortunate that their talents should be wasted on stuff so second-rate and loosely put together as the pieces we allude to.

div.head: "THE LITTLE MICHUS."
div.p: (BY TELEPHONE.)

The "Little Michus" was a great success last night, not only as a performance but as a play. It is in itself much above the usual standard of musical comedy; in fact, it is far more of the operetta, with a certain amount of musical dialogue, and even recitative, which is well put together, the parts being properly balanced, and the music being not only tasteful, but full of characterisation. Perhaps the most charming song of all was the duet between the Michus, addressed to St. Valentine.

Miss Corlass was at her best, and her voice, always delightful, was exceptionally so in this number. Mr. Harry Cole, as usual, repeatedly brought down the house. "Break Away" was an excellent piece of advice both to father and daughter, whom he surprises embracing their respective lovers. Mr. Will Smith was in much better form than we have yet seen him; the part gave him a fair chance and he profited by it. Mr. Attwell, too, did exceedingly well.

The only criticism one could make was that now and again the performance was a little bit ragged in the ensemble parts, the dialogue, and once or twice the chorus, but then, as we have said, the music is of very different character and arrangement to that of the average comedy. The piece is very charming, and all who were present greatly appreciated the performance.

div.head: INNISKILLINGS' RECONNAISSANCE.
div.p: The squadron of the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons, which is on a reconnaissance march through some of the provinces, arrived here from Tantah at ten o'clock this morning, and enjoyed an excellent breaktast, which was prepared for them by the local Omdeh. The Mamour strained every nerve to maintain order and security during the stay of the troops, and all the arrangements were perfect. The column, after expressing their warm thanks to the authorities, and the Omdeh in particular, proceeded to Shibin-el-Kom at eleven o'clock.

div.head: THE HEDJAZ RAILWAY
div.p: Marshal Kiazim: Pahba, Director General of the Hedjaz Railway, reports that most excellent work has been done by the soldiers employed on the railway. The rails are laid as far as kilometre 720. From this point up to kilometre 748 the building of forty bridges and tunnels was left entirely to the soldiers, and they have carried out the work most satisfactorily. Eight of the bridges were built in a fortnight. An economy of L. T. 8,000 has been realized by employing soldiers, who will carry out all the engineering works as far as Medina. A tunnel 160 metres long will be built near the station of Hissar

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Sir F. Reginald Wingate Pasha gave a dinner on Sunday evening to Ibrahim Pasha Fathy, Owen Bey, Naoum Bey Shonkeir, and Youssef Bffendi Sana, the Anglo-Egyptian members of the Frontier Commission.
Lady Wingate, who will arrive tomorrow from England, will give an "at home" on the 3rd prox. to the employés of the Ministry of War and those of the Sudan Government who are in Cairo.
Mazloum Pasha and Boutros Pasba Ghali arrived at Alexandria this morning by the Messagrries Maritimes mailboat Portugal.
Mr. Alfred Curphey, Mr. E. Thubron, and Mr. E. Long have arrived at Henry's Hotel, Paris, en route for Cairo. Mr. Curphey will make an automobile tour through Egypt during the coming season.

div.head:
COMPTOIR FINANCIER ET COMMERCIAL
ANNUAL GENERAL MEETING.
div.p: The ordinary general meeting of the shareholders of the Comptoir Financier et Commercial d'Egypte was held yesterday afternoon at the offices of the company in Alexandria. After the reading of the report of the directors, the chairman, M. A. Campos, said:—
MM.
Conformément aux articles 28 et 30 des Statuts, nous avons l'honneur de vous soumettre le Bilan et le compte "Profits et Pertes" de notre premier exercice soojal, clos le 31 Juillet 1906.
Vous nous permettrez on rapide exposé de Dos opérations depuis la création de votre Société.
Le Comptoir Financier a été constitué par Décret Khédivial on date du 29 Juin 1905, au capital de Lstg. 200,000 - représenté par :
50,000 actions ordinaires de Lstg. 4-chacune, émises au pair. Ce premier capital a été entièrement versé aux époques suivantes :
1er versement le 24/25 Juillet 1905
2ème ,, 1er Septembre ,,
3ème ,, 15 Ootobre ,,

Par votre vote da 7 Avril 1906, vous avez dans l'Assemblée Générale extraordinaire, convoquée à cette date, porté votre capital à Lstg. 400,000, par la création de 50,000 actions nouvelles de Lstg. 4, nominale, jouissance ler Août 1906, tout en nous donnant los pouvoirs nécessaires de le porter ultérieurement à Lstg. 500.000, par l'émission d'une nouvelle tranche de 25.000 actions.

L'émiesion des 50,000 actions a été faite an cours de Lstg. 5, soit avec une livre de prime et a été entièrement souscrite par les porteurs d'actions anciennes, en vertu da droit de préférence, que vous leur avez accordé.
Les versements ont été appelés aux époques 1 suivantes :
Lstg. 1, le 8 Mai ensemble avec la prime de Lstg. 1.
Lstg. 3, le 30 Septembre 1906.
La prime de Lstg. 1, dédudtion faite de la commission payée au syndicat de garantie, ainsi que des frais, a été portée en réserve et figure sur le Bilan sous la rubrique de "Réserve Bxtraordinaire."

Il nous suffira de vous déclarer que tous nos efforts ont bendu à établir dans le vaste champ d'activité, que vous nous avez ouvert, des bases solides et à développer dens notre périods de début, toutes les branches susceptibles de nous donner une source permanente de bénéfices.

Les reports en valeurs locales, qui ont été un des points importants de notre programme, ont eu toute notre attention et nous pouvons nous déclarer satisfaits des résultats acquis jusqu'ioi. Nous avons également traité quelques reports sur marchandises intéressantes à cortaines époques de l'années
Nos avances en comptes courants nantis à Alexandrie et au Caire nous ont assuré une clientèle, qui nous offre en dehors d'un placement plus stabie, la préférence de ses opérations.

Notre branche d'exécution d'ordres de bourse acquiert graduellement toute l'extension dont elle est susceptible et, tant en valeurs publiques qu’en cotons égyptien et américain, nous avons été amenée à traiter pour nos clients un chiffre très important.

Nous nous sommes enfio inté essés à toutes les opérations de banque en général, en établissant les divers services qu'elles comportent et en veillant à leur développement Nul doute que dans l'avenir plus encore que dans le présent ils n'apportent leur contingent de bénéfices stables.

Nos relations avec l'Etranger, auxquelles le récent voyage de notre Administrateur Délégué a donné quelque extension, suivent une progression satisfaisante. Tout en nous mettant en contact avec le Crédit européen, elles nous permettent de participer dans une certaine mesure, à côté de nos voisins, au mouvement d'affaires, créé par le Commerce égyptien d'importation et d'exportation.

Pour nous résumer, nous avons surtout cherché dans cette période initiale à grouper dans un esprit de prudence dont nous ne nous sommes jamais départis, tous les éléments qui assurent à votre Institution un rendement régulier et rémunérateur et les bénéfices de l'exercice ne sont que le résultat de nos efforts constants dans cette voie:

A ce point de vue et si l'on tient compte que notre premier exercice ne comprend qu'une période d'environ dix mois, nos opérations a Alexandrie n'ayant commencé effectivement que le 15 Septembre et ocelles de notre succursals du Caire qu'en Mars dernier, nous avons lieu de nous montrer satisfaits des comptes, que nous avons l'honneur de vous présenter hujourd'hui.
qui revient : 60 % aux actionnaires et 40 % aux parts de Fondateurs.

Sur ce solde nous vous proposons de répartir un dividende de 6% aux actionnaires soit P.TI 23 4/10, ce qui portera le dividende total de l'exercice à 12% et £2 par titre aux por teurs de parts de Fondateur.
serait à reporter à nouveau en compte "Parts de Fondateurs."

Répondant à une autre partie de notre programme, que nos affaires courantes de nous ont pas laissé le loisir d'exploiter davantage, nous avons, au cours de cet exercice, constitué un Syndicat de garantie pour assurer l'émission de la "Egypt, Levant Steam Oy’ Ld’ société anglaise au capital de Lstg: 200,000, — Nous avons reçu en échange de nou services 2,375 parte de Fondateur de la dite Société, qui figurent au Bilan pour le coût, soit 1/- per titre, bien que leur valeur effective soit de beaucoup supérieure."

Il n'y à nul doute que dans le période exceptionnellement prospère, que traverre l’Egypte, nous aurons p’us d'une foia ocoation de participer aux opérations financières, qui se présenteront. Là encore vous pouvez compter sur toute notre activité et toute notre prudence.
Divers projets intéressants que nous étudions de près ne manqueront pas, dans leur réalisation, d'assurer à votre Société en même temps qu'un développement normal, de nouvelles sources de bénéfices.

En attendant nous ne pouvons que constater le progrès gradual de nos affaires et sommes heureux de vous déclarer que les résultats des trois premiers mois du nouvel exercice nous font augurer favorablement de l'avenir.
Vous avez aussi à procéder à la nomination de deux Censeurs et à fixer lour allocation, MM. Paul Fabri et Marc Calamaro étant arrivés au terme de leur mandat.
En terminant, le Conseil est heureux d'exprimer sa satisfaction pour les services rendus par tout le personnel du Siège social ainai que de la Succursale du Caire.

The acoounts for the year ending July 31 were unanimously approved, as were also the dividends proposed, and the retiring auditors, Messrs. Marc Calamaro and Paul Fabri, were re-elected for the ensuing year.

A Shareholder proposed a vote of thanks to M. Alfred Campos, managing director, and all the members of the board, as well de Mr. Benvenuto Campos, general manager. This was seconded and passed unanimously
M. Campos and the board of directors are certainly to be congratulated on the very excellent results which have attended the company's first year's operations.

div.head: NEW CO-OPERATIVE STORES.
div.p: Caffari's Co-operative Markets, Limited, a co-operative society founded last August in London, will definitely commence operations in Cairo on Thursday.

This new venture is but the continuation of the business hitherto carried on by the well known firm of John B. Caffari situated in Kasr-el-Nil, between the Anglo-Egyptipn Bank and the headquarters of the Army of Occupation. The premises, however, have been thoroughly renovated and enlarged, and arranged in special departments for every description of goods. Annexed to this is a fine shop, built on the latest sanitary and up-to-date model. The managing director and general manager is Mr. John B. Caffari, whose business ability is so widely known. The premises are well aired and filled with a rich assortment of first-class goods at moderate prices. A well trained staff will attend to orders with utmost promptness The following is a list of the various departments:
Dept. A.-—All kinds of groceries of the latest sort, from France, England, and Italy.
Dept. B.—Wines (of Italian, French, and German vintage), beers and liqueurs, and general drinks.
Dept. C.—Silver goods, perfumes, etc.
Dept. D.—Crystal ware, stores, culinary utensils, eto.
Dept. E.—Drugs.
The stores department consists of the following:—Fresh and salt meat of first quality, sausages, fish, fresh and dried, salt fish, and game, fresh vegetables, dessert fruit.

The advantage offered to the poblic are many. Besides the convenience of being able, by one walk through the premises, to procure all one's household needs for the month, being sure of getting all of the best quality, and the pleasure of having a prompt and free delivery of goods at the house, the prices are indisputably low. The annual subscription for members is P.T. 40. According to the statates of the company members are entitled to 40% dividend yearly

The Ellerman S.S. Britannia sailed from Liverpool last Sunday for Malta and Alexandria with passengers and a general cargo.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie.)

Les réalisations ont entrainé une légère réaction partielle ; que’ques valeurs sont oe. pendant, on hausse. Comme affaires, elles ont ou de l'importance en National Bank, Salt & Soda, Cassa di Sconto, Delta Land, Nile Land, Estates, Comptoir et Crédit Franco-Egyptien.

L'Agricole recule de 9 13/16 à 9 25/32, la National Bank de 27 5/16 à 27 1/4, l'Obligation Crédit Foncier do 336 à 335 l'ancienne et de 271 ½ à 271 la nouvelle, la Cassa di Sconto de 239 1/2 à 238 3/4 l'ancienne et de 234 ½ à 233 1/4 la nonvelle ; par contre, le Banco di Roma remonte de 112 à 113, la Banque d'Orient de 133 1/2 à 134 et les Lots Trrcs de 146 à 147.

De 45 1/2 la Béhéra retombe à 45 et la Delta Land de 4 1/16 à 4 1/32, tandis que la Nile Lund s'avance de 16 7/16 à 16 13/16 et la Building Lands de 4 29/32 à 4 31/32; l'Urbaine et l'Union Foncière sont en excellente tendance aux prix respectifs de 6 7/16 et 6 1/2 acheteors.

Parmi les valeurs industrielles, il y a également partage entre la hausse et la baisse : les Markets montent de 27 å 27/3, la Bière du Caire de 131 à 135 la Privilégiés et de 68 à 72 3/4 la Dividende, les Cotton Mills de 6/1 1/2 à 6/3, l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 35/6 à 35/9 et les Splendid Hotels de 4 1/16 à 4 1/8, tandis que les Nuogovich Hotels réactionnent de 18 7/16 à 18 1/4, les Sucrerie, de 25 à 23, et la privilégiée Khedivial Mail de 4 3/4 8 4 5/8.

Le Comptoir est ferme à 6 28/32 la noavelle et 6 31/32 l'ancienne ; la part de fondateur s'avance même de 49 1/2 à 50. L'assemblée générale, qui s'est tenue hier après midi, a décidé la distribution d'un dividende de 6% aux actionnaires, soit P.T. 23 4/10, ce qui, avec le dividende intérimaire, fait un total de 12%, et £2 aux parts de fondateur.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: La Caire, Octobre 29.

Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres est tonjours renseigné à 5 k pour cent. Avant-hier, au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais est resté invarié à 86 1/8, de même que l'Unifiée à 104. La National Bank a haussé de 1/8 à 27 1/2. L'Agricole est demeurée inchangée à 9 7/8, la Daïra à 17 et la Delta Light à 12.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a rétrogradé de 2 francs à 780 et la Banque d'Athènes de 1 franc á 145.

En dépit de la persistance de la tension monétaire à Londres et de la oberté de l'argent sur place, notre marché des valeurs maintient et accentue même ses bonnes dispositions. La cote conserve daus son ensemble une orientation excellente en présence du fait acquis que la liquidation de fin de mois se terminera sans encombre, la plupart des positions ayant été reportées fin Novembre.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National a cltôturé plus ferme à 27 5/16, de même que l'Agricole à 9 13/16. La Banque d'Athènes s'est raffermie à 145-146. Le Comptoir Financier, dont l'assemblée générale ordinaire a lieu cet après midi à Alexandrie, s'est maintenu à 7; la part de fondateur a progressé à 50.
Le Crédit Foncier est resté à 780; les obligations à lots, anciennes et nouvelies, ont rétrogradé de 1 franc à 335-337 et 269-270.

Il y a eu un très fort mouvement sur la Béhéra, qui a haussé jusqu'a 47 pour réactionner à 45 1/2-3'4 sur des réalisations. On s'attendrait à la continuation du mouvement, car, suivant des données complémentaires, les actionnaires suraient, paralt-il, la perspective d'encaisser L.E. 17, au lieu de 14, dans le courant de cet exercice. L'Union Foncière a fait 6 1/2-9/16.

La Nile Land a avancé à 16 5/16. L'action Immobilière s'est maintenue à 382 ; la part de fondateur est remontée à 725-730. L'Enterprise and Development a progressé à 12 13/16-7/8 et la part de fondateur à 22-22 1/4. Les Improvements se sont consolidés à 6 5/16-3/8. L'Allotment s'est raffermi à 3 15/16-4 ; la part de fondateur a fléchi à 164. Les Emtreprises Immobilières et Travaux ont été traitées à 4 1/2 9/16; la part de fondsteur a progressé à 98-99. Fortement recherchée, la part do fondateur Gharbieh a gagné 1/2 livre à 2 3/4
Les actions de capital Eaux du Caire se sont tassées à 122-123 et les Frigorifiques à 4 3/4-13/16. Les Aatomobiles sont revenue, à 6 5/16 et leur part de fondateur à 11 3/4.
L'action Express Nile a été encore recherchée et a c’ôturé en avance de 1/8 à 4 3/16 : la part de fondateur s'est consolidée à 109.

Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovich et les Egyptian ont été néglige à leurs cours précédents. Les Upper Egypt se sont alourdis à 5 5/8-11/16. Les honneurs de la séance dans ce compartiment ont été pour les Excelsior, qui ont atteint, au début 4 7/8 pour fléchir à 4 5/16, remonter à 4 3/4 et clôturer à 4 5/8 11/16 ; la part de fondatour est montée à 2 1/4 pour finir à 2 5/32

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont avancé à 4 1/8 pour terminer plas faibles à 4 1/16. Très mouvementés et largement traité,s au début, aux abords de 2 5/16-3/8, les Estates sont revenus en clôture à 2 1/4 ; leur part de fondateur a progressé à 15 1/2, 9/.6. Les New Egyptian ont faibli á 33/6 33/9 Les Salt and Soda sont remontés à 24 sh. Le Markets se sont raffermis à 27 sh. 6. Les avis ont rétrogradé à 15/16.
Une réunion privée d'actionnaires de la Société des Excelsior Hotels a été tenue samedi passé an Caire. Les assistants représentaient près de 8,000 actious, soit environ 20 % du capital social.

L'assemblée a approuvé l'objet de la réunion ainsi que les conclusions présentées. Elle a cbargé uu de ses membres de la représenter auprès du conseil d'administration et de rédiger la lettre à adresser à celui-ci en vue de la convocation d'une assemblée générale extraordinaire à l'efist de discuter les propositions dont s'agit.
L'Egyptian Estates Co. a mis en vente ses terrains sis à Alexandrie, quartier Moharrem Bey, rue Erfhan-Pachs, par lots de mille pics, avec facilités de paiement pour les acheteurs.

On persiste à prétendre, dans certains milieux, que le conseil d'administration se proposerait de liquider tont l'actif en terrains et immenbles, de procéder ensuite au doublement du capital, qui serait aiusi porté de £500,000 à 1,000,000, et enfin de transformer la Société en Banque hypothécaire et de prêts.
C'est à ces rumeurs, qui, d'ailleurs, ne datant pas d'hier et dont il est difficile de certifier l'exactitude, qu'il faut attribuer la hausse récente du titre.

A en croire des informations ébruitées à Alexandrie, la nouvelle émission de la Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio, tendant à porter le capital de cette Banque de 10 à 20 milliens de trancs, aurait lieu en mars prochain.

Il se confirme que le terrain disponible de la Walker and Meimarachi Ltd., rue El-Madabegh, où la Société va construire ses nouveaux magasins, a été vendu pour la somme de 56,000 livres. Il s'agit de près de 2,250 mètres carrés, ce qui ramènerait le mètre aux environs de 25 livres.

div.head: DERNIERE HEURE

Cours de l'Association des Courtiers en Marchandises

It is understood in naval circles that Sir William May will succeed Sir Charles Drury as second Sea-lord. Sir Day Bosanquet will replace Sir Archibald Douglas at Portsmouth. Rear-Admiral Bridgeman will be the first commandant of the Home Fleet. Sir Assheton Curzon-Howe will succeed Sir W. May in the command of the Atlantic Fleet. Rear-Admiral Poe will succeed Rear-Admiral Darnford in the command-in-chief, Cape of Good Hope.(R.)

The Admiralty confirms the naval appointments mentioned yesterday, and adds that Rear-Admiral F. W. Fisher has been appointed Superintendent of the Malta dock-yard. Lord Charles Beresford has been appointed to the Channel Fleet. Prince Louis of Battenberg has been appointed second in command of the Mediterranean Fleet. Rear-Admiral Inglefield has been appointed to the Fourth Cruiser Squadron, and Rear Admiral Charles Adair to the Second Cruiser Squadron. (Reuter)

div.head: PERSIA.
PRESERVING THE STATUS QUO.
div.p: HOUSE OF COMMONS.–Mr. Runciman, asked whether an agreement had been reached with Russia relating to Persia, replied that no general agreement had been arrived at. The British and Russian Governments had discussed the recent events in Persia with the object of avoiding conflict of interest and of acting together when possible in order to preserve the status quo. (Reuter)

div.head: RIFLE SHOOTING IN SCHOOLS.
div.p: The Labourites and extreme Radicals are agitating against Mr. Birrell's decision of the 30th August with regard to rifle shooting in schools. Mr. Snowden and Mr. Macnamara have given notice of questions on the subject.
(Reuter)

div.head: AMERICAN TRAIN DISASTER.
TRAIN PRECIPITATED INTO WATER
div.p: An electric train, comprised of three cars, while crossing the swing bridge over the waterway separating Atlantic City from the mainland, became derailed and fell into thirty feet of water, Forty-four bodies have been recovered, but it is believed that at least twenty-five are still submerged. (Reuter)

div.head: THE MOROCCO TROUBLE.
APPROACHING SETTLEMENT.
div.p: M. Pichon stated at the Council of Ministers that the Morocco affair was on the way to settlement. (Havas)

div.head: THE KOEPENICK ROBBERY.
VOIGT’S APPEARANCE IN COURT.
div.p: The police court was convulsed with laughter when Voigt, who is an old man with a weatherbeaten begrimed face and crooked nose and horny hands, appeared in the dock. (Reuter)

div.head: AUSTRIA AND ITALY.
div.p: Baron Lexa d'Aehrenthal has notified the Italian Embassy at Vienna that he desires a meeting with Signor Tittoni. It is believed that the interview will take place here. (Reuter)

div.head: RECOVERY OF LUTIN'S VICTIMS.
div.p: All the bodies have been got out of the Lutin. (Havas)

div.head: FUNERAL OF RAKOSKY.
div.p: The translation of the remains of Rakosky was carried out with great solemnity. (Havas)

div.head: BEYROUT HARBOUR.
ITS RELATION TO TRADE.
div.p: Our Correspondent at Beyrout writes :

It is at the same time curious and sad to note that the two great public enterprises of the French in Syria have had abortive results. I refer to the railway system, embodying the narrow cogwheel line between Beyrout, Damascus, and Mezerib, and the subservient broad line between Beyrout, Homs-Hams, and Aleppo; and to the Beyrout habour. Both enterprises are marked with an astonishing immaturity of conception, and an utter lack of foresight and sober calculation. Both enterprises were undertaken when Syria and Beyrout were yet in their infancy, in so far as local and foreign trade movement is concerned; and the initiators of both schemes plead this fact to justify their limited character. The initiators of the Beyrout harbour scheme are still less justifiable because of their knowledge of the eventual realization of the railway schemes that have since materialized, and have, by the sudden impetus they have imparted to the trade of Syria, thrown the harbour into the disorder, confusion, and congestion from which it is now suffering, and which is reacting so disastrously on the trade and shipping of the town. But fortunately, while the evil of the railway enterprise is irremediable, unless the narrow cogwheel line be superseded by a broad gauge one to meet the Rayak-Aleppo section, that of the harbour is susceptible of reform through a moderate outlay of capital that would be more than amply justified.

Two years ago the Custom House was so congested that hundreds of tons of valuable cargo had to lie for several days and nights in the lighters, exposed to the inclemencies of the weather and to theft. The evil was so great that all the steamship agents rose in protest against this scandalous state of things. The different Consulates and Embassies took the matter ap energetically, with the result that the reform of the Turkish Customs, and particularly our Custom House, and the proper working of it and the port as well, was laid down by the Powers lately as a condition of their acceptance of the increased Customs duty which the Ottoman Government so much desires. The enlargement of the Customs grounds and warehouses, and the extension of the working hours were among the principal conditions of the reform demanded. It has been proposed to fill up the small basin between Mole B and C and build there an annex. This would certainly be a very valuable addition to our Custom House, the requirements of which in the matter of room are increasing daily. But what is of immediate necessity—and it is absolutely inconceivable how the Port Company has so far neglected it—is the installation of proper hoisting apparatus. Persons living in a civilized sea port would hardly believe that all the French Port Company has in this line is a weak hand crane on the outer Customs quay, and another still weaker one on the main quay for the discharge of railway material and iron joists. They have, moreover, a floating crane of ten-ton capacity. All these primitive appliances are constantly getting out of order, and the consequent evils and annoyances to trade are indescribable. I have just paid a visit to the Customs grounds, and the sight was both pitiful and disgusting. All the outer Customs quay and the stores inside were jammed with goods, principally bale cargo, and steamers have now to discharge their cargo in lighters and keep them there for several days until the congestion is eased. And to think that all this harm to innocent trade might be avoided by a trifling expense in the shape of another crane or two, and especially the installation of one which might lift the goods and pile them in order inside the Custom House, or on to an upper floor which might be easily built on the top of the present warehouses!

The whole area of the harbour is about 20 hectares, and when one considers that a pretty large part thereof is occupied by the smaller craft, such as sailing vessels and lighters, the limited space left for steamers can be realized. There is scarcely any swinging room when the number of ships anchoring simultaneously in the harbour exceeds 8 or 10, and that anchors should run foul of each other is inevitable. There is no berth accommodation except alongside the quay of the "traverse" which can accommodate only three steamers of average size. The Ottoman Bank and the Anglo-Syrian Trading Company have distinguished themselves by transporting zino warehouses from England, thus offering to trade the great facility of direct shipment from shore to ship without the intermediate use of lighters. But the purpose for which these warehouses were built has been nullified to a certain extent by the absurdly limited capacity of the traverse quay. Instead of leaving this small quay free for the use of the trade the Port Company is utilizing it, against all rules of justice and common sense, for the discharge of coals and railway material such as iron and cement, all destined for the Railway Company with which the Port Company is amalgamated. Recently three colliers kept discharging on that quay for over ten days, monopolizing the only three berths available for shipping, and the merchant ships had to load from lighters, though they had hired at an extra cost those stores on the quay to avoid this lighterage expense with its attendant risks. The stores are not only blocked op with huge mounds of coal which seriously hamper the movements of the labourers carrying the stuff from the stores to the ship alongside, and, at the same time threaten the solidity of the wallsides, but the coal dust is a constant annoyance to the merchants who have their grain or other cargo in those stores.

The above and other evils have become a veritable public scandal. Fortunately, however, Mr. Chenut, Vice President and Administrator of the Régie Générale des Chemins de fer, was here lately to attend the inauguration of the Hama-Aleppo section of the railway, and at the same time to study on the spot the many grievances against both concerns. He proposes to lay before the Board of Directors the excellent idea of broadening the traverse so that steamers shall be able to come alongside at the other end, thus doubling the berthing accommodation, and increasing also the storage room for goods. Although that part of the outer harbour immediately along the right side of the traverse is fairly well protected as it is, yet to ensure the safety of steamers taking their berth thereat, it will probably be necessary to prolong the breakwater; but in that case the end just alluded to will not only be served, but also all that fine natural bay which now constitutes the outer harbour will be converted into a spacious and regular harbour that can accommodate the shipping of a great port. The draught there is so deep that there will be scarcely any need for dredging, and therefore the expense required for the consummation of such an important and valuable project will be comparatively very small, and will surely be more than justified. We hope to hear soon that this additional outlay has been voted by the company's board.

It will be appropriate to give bere a few statistical figures to show the degree of importance of the shipping movement of the port of Beyrout. In the year 1903 there were cleared 918 steamers of a total register tonnage of 1,037,785 and 3,197 sailing vessels of 92,166 tons, making a grand total of 1,129,951 tons. In the following year, 1904, the clearances were 991 steamers of 1,188,826 tons and 2,474 sailing vessels of 63,272 tons making a grand total of 1,252,098 tons register. Last year the total of steamers cleared was 908, of 1,187,487, while that of sailing vessels was 2,269, of 53,111 tons, totaling in all 1,240,598 tons register. Out of this total steamship tonnage, 285 steamers of 338,128 tons register are British, and this is again a superfluous testimony to the preponderance of British maritime influence in the world.

Such figures as I have given are enough to show that a small harbour of 20 hectares, such as the French have built for Beyrout, is wholly inadequate; and the development of railway enterprise, and the trade activities that have followed in its wake, make enlargement an urgent necessity.

In the event of the new project being accomplished, the building of a special collier quay will be indispensable. As both the narrow and broad railways, between Beyrout, Damascus, and Aleppo and the short light suburban railway between Beyrout and Maameltein have to be supplied with their necessary coals at Beyrout, the construction of such a quay is a manifest necessity.

Amongst the many grievances of trade that call for immediate attention is the question of store room. Here the Port and Railway Companies have shown the most unwarrantable unconcern which has, however, been reacting on them with serious disadvantage. With the same short-sighted policy the company has allowed itself to be lured by immediate profits, and sold a good part of valuable land reclaimed from the sea for the construction of hotels and cafés instead of insisting on such land being mainly utilized for warehouses to help in easing the congested traffic and also assist indirectly the railway with which its interests are indissolubly bound up. A part of the remaining land available has been sold lately to the Imperial Ottoman Bank and other private merchants who destine it for such a purpose. But as these stores lie somewhat far out of the way, the purpose of economical shipment cannot be fully served. There remains, however, some land yet that may fully answer this purpose owing to its proximity to the main quay edge. Here again the Anglo-Syrian Trading Company, Ltd., and another enterprising and well-known French firm have come forward with the offer to the Port Company of renting this land for warehouse purposes, for a certain number of years, but with the option of buying up the land at the expiration of the lease. The demand was most fair, but the company, in utter disregard of the railway interests, has refused the option of purchase.

The negotiations for the purchase of the quay land were started by the director of the Railway Company, but arriving at the decisive point the matter had to be referred to and left in the hands of the Port Company. In the meantime, the Railway Company is confronted with a sore problem. As the trucks arrive from Damascus and Homs-Hama the receivers cannot reasonably take immediate delivery of their goods, and the company, to free its rolling stock, unceremoniously throws the goods on the open quay, with the result that the goods are liable to be damaged by rain and from other causes, as well as theft; while the quay traffic is at the same time seriously encumbered. Incredible as it may seem, the Railway Company has declared lately that in addition to this vexatious treatment it intends to tax such goods as are not removed immediately after their discharge from the trucks, with the avowed object of compelling the merchants to buy up the yet available quay space at the dictated prices and onerous terms of the Port Company The worthy directors of these French concerns do not seem to realize that they are in a land not quite trained yet to modern business methods, and lacking constitutionally the Western spirit of organized enterprise. They do not seem to realize that in a land like the indolent, poor, and fatalist East the first step should be taken by the exploiting concern, and the people must first be helped to stand on their legs before they can return their debt. Here, again, Mr. Chenut seem to have fully grasped the situation, and it is only to he hoped that he will succeed in making the Administration at Paris see with his eyes,

div.head: NEW CAIRO.
TRANSFORMATION OF BOULAC.
div.p: A Cairo contemporary says:—

The numerous projects, which the general plans for the embellishment and enlargement of Cairo, drawn up by the Ministry of Public Works and approved by the Government, comprise, have for some months, after a lengthy period of gestation, assumed a practical and active form.

Hardly had the construction of the Ghizeh bridge, whose arches to-day span the Nile, and which will be opened to traffic in February, been begun, than the Government turned its attention to the preparatory works for the Boulac bridge. In January of this year the plans were finished, the construction decided upon, and the points at which the bridge would begin and end were determined. The inspection of the preliminary work of the expropriation of the necessary lands and the enlargement of Sharia Boalac from the Halim Pasha building and the Continental Hotel were in the hands of old scholars of the Arts and Crafts School. The Ministry of Finance at the same time decided to set aside a sum of L.E 50,000 for the indemnities arising from these expropriations.

From that time the construction of a bridge, which the interests of the town imperiously claimed, might be considered as a thing decided upon, if not done. The Government appeared at last to have repaired the mistake with which it was reproached, i.e abandon the real Cairo in order to create for speculators distant suburbs for them to exploit.

With Ghezireh joined to the Esbekich, we have the orientation of the capital towards its real topographical destiny, and it is that which we have always demanded. To rid Boulac of its filthy and unhealthy dwellings, and let light and air have free play, is another step towards meeting the economic requirements of Cairo.

As soon as these works were decided upon the landlords at Boulac began to consider the laying out on their lands of new avenues opening on to the wide and magnificent boulevard which the present avenue, now so dirty and badly kept, will become—in a word, to attract promenaders and retain the inhabitants of the quarter.

One of the big landlords in Boalac, Mr. Turgoman, who owns 150,000 square metres in this quarter, was the first to set the example, by turning out the inhabitants of the huts standing on his land. This example, the advantage of which the other landlords have not been slow to appreciate, will be followed without delay. The whole of the quarter will, therefore, rapidly change aspect and the access to Ghezireh by way of Boulac will become most pleasant and attractive.

The lands skirting the Boulac boulevard and the future adjoining avenues are not the only ones whose future is entering upon a new era of prosperity. Ghezireh island will also benefit by the construction of the new bridge, even more so than the right bank of the Nile. It is difficult to foresee the very great development which will attend the passage of the tramway line from Ataba el Khadra, Boulac, Pont des Anglais, and the Pyramids. This line is sure to be the most patronised and to create a great stir on the charming island of Ghezireh. By this means of communication the centre of Ghezireh will only be a few minutes' ride from the centre of the city.

The appearance of the bridge avenue on this side of the Nile will be quite different to that of the boulevards on the island flanked by handsome villas and cottages; the avenue will, it appears, be formed of blocks, each comprising several flats and have shops on the ground floor. The buildings lining the avenue will not be the only ones to receive tenants. Ghezireh gardens have, it is said, sold several of their plots with permission to construct flats.

On the other hand it is believed that next January the Ghezireh Land Company will go into liquidation and there can be no doubt that a meeting of landlords, who will become then masters of the situation, will decide to abolish the restrictive clauses of the cahier des charges at present in force. Each one may then build villas, shops, or blocks as he likes on the lands belonging to him. It is, therefore, safe to forecast for the island an immense development and a considerable increase of population, brought about by the construction of the new Boulac bridge, the laying of the tramway line, and the building of blocks.

We are not alone in foreseeing so prosperous a future for Ghezireb, and we are scarcely doing more than resuming the opinion of the public which has long since manifested itself by the rise in shares of Egyptian Hotels, issued at £1, for which it was difficult to find buyers at 15s. and which are now quoted at £7.10. This rise is not based simply on the prosperity of the hotels, but more so on the increased value of the Ghezireh Gardens land, arising from the works referred to.

The scheme of a quay promenade 30 metres wide between Kasr el Nil and Boulac bridges, which has been so long under consideration, has also just been decided. This fresh artery, which will be a splendid promenade, will also invest Ghezireh with a host of other charms

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Avances sur titres;
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
